awd_titl_txt: Initial Perturbations on Ultra-Small Scales and Primordial Black Holes in the Era of Gravitational-Wave Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Yacine Ali-Haimoud at New York University.

After decades of increasingly detailed observations, it is well established that the Universe contains a large amount of unknown matter that interacts little, if at all, with known forms of matter. Understanding the nature of this "dark matter" is one of the major unsolved problems in physics.  Primordial black holes (PBH's) are fascinating dark-matter candidates.  PBH's could have formed in the infant Universe, before the first stars even existed.  Professor Ali-Haimoud aims to develop tests of PBH's by predicting their effect on maps of the early Universe and examining the gravitational waves they would emit, and by comparing these predictions with observations. In addition, he will develop a novel way to study the initial conditions of the Universe by quantifying their impact on certain cosmological phase transitions.  As such, this research serves the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental science in the United States.  This research will also have significant broader impacts.  Professor Ali-Haimoud will include the results of this research in his graduate and undergraduate physics courses and will also directly engage students in these investigations.  In addition, he will develop a course for underserved New York City high-school students on the physics of sailing in which he hopes to foster enthusiasm for physics by drawing parallels between sailing and gravitational waves and black holes. 

More specifically, the first and main focus of this research is to establish robust limits on the abundance of PBH's of about one to one thousand solar masses through their impact on cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies, and especially their gravitational-wave signals for the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO).  Professor Ali-Haimoud will extend his analytic calculations of the merger rate of PBH binaries to realistic mass distributions, estimate the resulting stochastic gravitational-wave background accounting for high eccentricities, and establish through numerical simulation whether PBH binaries formed in the early Universe are significantly affected by non-linear structures.  He will also extend his work on CMB limits by estimating the self-consistent luminosity of accreting PBH's, and by studying the nature of accretion (spherical vs. disk-like).  The second project involves exploring an entirely new idea:  the impact of small-scale baryon perturbations on the global recombination history.  This effect can probe the currently unconstrained small-scale baryon isocurvature perturbation.  Professor Ali-Haimoud will explore this idea quantitatively by studying perturbed radiative transfer in the Lyman-alpha line during recombination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on two overarching themes: 1) primordial black holes, a fascinating candidate for the unknown dark matter, and 2) the initial density perturbations in the early Universe on very small length scales, much smaller than can directly be probed by cosmological data. These two themes are interconnected since PBHs could have formed out of the collapse of large-amplitude densitiy perturbations in the early Universe.

1) The first part of the project aims to tudy the observable effects of primordial black holes on the cosmic microwave background (CMB), as well as their gravitational-wave signatures.

  • The PI and his graduate student Trey Jensen completed two articles on a novel effect of primordial black holes in the CMB, namely non-Gaussian signatures, resulting from the large spatial fluctuations in the luminosity of primordial black holes. This novel signature is promising, as it can be a lot more sensitive to primordial black holes than the standard CMB power spectrum, which neglects any non-Gaussian signatures. The next steps will be to compute the polarization counterpart of the signal. 
  • The PI and postdoc Derek Inman implemented the very first numerical simulations of mixed particle and primordial black hole dark matter. They showed that primordial black holes can significantly enhance the rate at which the first non-linear structures form in the Early Universe. Their results will be used in future work to estimate the effect of non-linear structures on the survival of primordial black hole binaries, hence on their merger rate.

2) The second part of the project aims to develop a novel probe of ultra-small-scale initial density perturbations, through their indirect effect on the CMB. The PI and his student Nanoom Lee developed a new theoretical formalism to calculate how unresolved density perturbations can affect the rate at which the first atoms form in the early Universe (the process of cosmological recombination). They demonstrated that the perturbations to recombination can leave an imprint in CMB statistics, and used this result to derive new upper limits on the density perturbations in the early Universe, on length scales which are ususally too small to be directly studied.

The results of this work are published in several peer-review publications in Physical Review D.

In addition to the direct scientific outputs, the PI undertook several activities for broader impacts.

  • The PI prepared visually exciting pedagogical materials on cosmological recombination and the cosmic microwave background, made available on https://cosmo.nyu.edu/yacine/teaching/warner/warner.html. This public website especially targets undergraduate students and their instructors. 
  • The PI participated in several interviews for broad-audience science magazines and websites: Symmetry Magazine (https://www.symmetrymagazine.org/article/what-gravitational-waves-can-say-about-dark-matter), Astrobites (https://astrobites.org/2019/06/07/meet-the-aas-keynote-speakers-professor-yacine-ali-haimoud/), Sky and Telescope (https://www.skyandtelescope.com/astronomy-news/black-holes/could-dark-matter-be-black-holes/), and APS news website (https://physics.aps.org/articles/v11/99). 
  • The PI made a presentation in an introductory astrophysics course at Darmouth university in August 2020. 
  • In addition to mentoring the graduate students and postdoc involved in this research, the PI mentored a high-school student for an introductory project related to primordial black hole mergers.
